heuristic:
<heuristic>
To locate and resolve the "undefined method" bugs that were illustrated in several code snippets provided:

1. Identify the error message that indicates an undefined or not found method, usually, this comes from your compiler or runtime environment. The message typically includes the name of the missing method.
   
2. Using the name of the missing method (e.g., calculatorBlockSum, ArrayUtils.sort, undefinedMethod, checkAdditionalCondition, swapp, myMin), search the entire codebase to confirm the absence of its definition. This can be done using a text search feature in your text editor or IDE.

3. Once confirmed that the method is indeed missing, decide on an approach to resolve the issue. The options generally are:
   - Define the missing method if it’s supposed to be part of the class or package. This involves writing the complete method according to what its intended functionality is supposed to be.
   - If the missing method is supposed to come from an external library or package, ensure that the library is correctly imported or included in the project. Double-check the documentation of the library to ensure the correct method name and usage.
   - Replace the call to the missing method with an equivalent piece of code that achieves the same result if defining or importing the method is not feasible.

4. Replace or correct the method call by ensuring the method exists or changing it to a method that produces the desired effect. If creating a new method, write the method above or below the current class methods, or in the appropriate section of your project where it logically fits.

5. After implementing or correcting the method, compile and run your code again to ensure the issue is resolved. Check for logical and runtime errors in your new or modified method to make sure it behaves as expected.

6. If the issue persists or another error appears, repeat the process focusing on the new information provided by the error messages or by carefully reviewing the logic and structure of your code.

This heuristic approach helps in systematically pinpointing and correcting "undefined method" errors by ensuring the methods required by your codebase are correctly defined, available, and utilized.
</heuristic>
